Award.AwardTitle: Automated Computational Modeling and Adaptive Control for Critical Patient Resuscitation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Physicians face enormous challenges in making decisions to resuscitate and stabilize critically ill and injured patients based on rapidly changing vital signs. This project will investigate automated processing of physiological measurements, using high-speed computational models to provide near-instantaneous treatment recommendations to stabilize blood pressure, cardiac output and renal function. Additionally, feedback control algorithms will be developed capable of automatically regulating the administration of drugs and fluids to optimize critical care, subject to the specific physiological state of the patient. This advance in continually monitored and adjusted personalized treatment is expected to benefit patients suffering from trauma, burn, infection, and shock. The resulting decision assistance system and adaptive closed-loop drug and fluid delivery system will greatly benefit the accuracy and reliability of critical care treatments, resulting in increased survival rates and improved therapeutic outcomes.

The project will develop adaptive models of cardio-vascular and fluid response, subject to the injection of vasoactive drugs and fluid therapy. The corresponding drug and fluid administration problem is challenged by a changing physiological dynamic response and a significant time-delay in the response due to drug absorption. Multi-model observers will be investigated to provide instantaneous dosage recommendations to doctors to achieve targeted values of blood pressure, cardiac output and urinary output. The models will compute the patient's responsiveness to various drugs and fluids, and will self-adapt to varying responses to treatment from patient-to-patient and within a single patient over time (intra-patient and inter-patient variability). Detection algorithms will be developed to identify potential sudden changes in the patient's physiological response, such as the presence of an internal hemorrhage, and alert the doctors. Additionally, model-based adaptive and robust closed-loop drug infusion algorithms will be developed to automate the drug administration process for optimized patient resuscitation. The research team will collaborate with medical experts that will provide physiological data from animal experiments and will assist in the evaluation of the developed models and decision support algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has developed methodologies and algorithms for the automated administration of drugs in critical care patients to regulate their physiological response to desired targets. Specific focus has been the automated regulation of the mean arterial pressure (MAP) using vasoactive drug infusion to achieve patient hemodynamic stability in emergency care resuscitation. Simplified first order delay dynamic models of the blood pressure response to vasoactive drugs were developed that include adjustable parameters (drug sensitivity and time constant) that can be estimated in real-time to capture a specific patients' MAP dynamics. The models also include a variable time delay term to address the drug infusion delay and the pharmacodynamic delay on the physiological response. Model-based linear parameter varying control algorithms in combination with real-time parameter estimation algorithms have been developed to provide MAP response regulation to desired targets in the presence of physiological response variability and drug infusion magnitude and rate saturation constraints. Additionally, the developed model-parameter estimation algorithms provide the capability for computerized decision support to assist doctors with vasopressor drug dosage recommendations. 

The project has advanced the state-of-the art in the linear parameter varying robust control of uncertain systems with time-varying delays and saturation constraints. Delay-dependent and parameter dependent controllers to guarantee closed-loop stability and disturbance rejection constraints have been developed utilizing a Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional approach following the solution of convex linear matrix inequality optimization problems. Additionally, the project has progressed the knowledgebase in real-time parameter estimation of dynamic systems with variable delays utilizing a cubature Kalman filtering approach. The parameter estimation algorithms have been validated using animal experiment data in vasopressor support studies. The closed-loop MAP control algorithms have been validated using developed MAP patient response simulation models that capture the physiological response variability.  

The undergraduate and graduate students that have been involved in the project have acquired interdisciplinary skills in modeling and control combined with physiological principles. The project has advanced their technical knowledge and expertise on systems modeling, system parameter identification, parameter estimation, and systems analysis and feedback control for time-delay and time-varying systems. The project was conducted in collaboration with the Resuscitation Research Laboratory at the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). UTMB provided animal experiment data and medical expertise support. Project results have been transferred to UTMB to benefit patient decision support and computerized drug delivery studies. Additionally, project results have been disseminated via multiple conference and journal publications and the PhD Theses of two graduate students.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project has developed methodologies and algorithms for the automated administration of drugs in critical care patients to regulate their physiological response to desired targets. Specific focus has been the automated regulation of the mean arterial pressure (MAP) using vasoactive drug infusion to achieve patient hemodynamic stability in emergency care resuscitation. Simplified first order delay dynamic models of the blood pressure response to vasoactive drugs were developed that include adjustable parameters (drug sensitivity and time constant) that can be estimated in real-time to capture a specific patients' MAP dynamics. The models also include a variable time delay term to address the drug infusion delay and the pharmacodynamic delay on the physiological response. Model-based linear parameter varying control algorithms in combination with real-time parameter estimation algorithms have been developed to provide MAP response regulation to desired targets in the presence of physiological response variability and drug infusion magnitude and rate saturation constraints. Additionally, the developed model-parameter estimation algorithms provide the capability for computerized decision support to assist doctors with vasopressor drug dosage recommendations. The project has advanced the state-of-the art in the linear parameter varying robust control of uncertain systems with time-varying delays and saturation constraints. Delay-dependent and parameter dependent controllers to guarantee closed-loop stability and disturbance rejection constraints have been developed utilizing a Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional approach following the solution of convex linear matrix inequality optimization problems. Additionally, the project has progressed the knowledgebase in real-time parameter estimation of dynamic systems with variable delays utilizing a cubature Kalman filtering approach. The parameter estimation algorithms have been validated using animal experiment data in vasopressor support studies. The closed-loop MAP control algorithms have been validated using developed MAP patient response simulation models that capture the physiological response variability. The undergraduate and graduate students that have been involved in the project have acquired interdisciplinary skills in modeling and control combined with physiological principles. The project has advanced their technical knowledge and expertise on systems modeling, system parameter identification, parameter estimation, and systems analysis and feedback control for time-delay and time-varying systems. The project was conducted in collaboration with the Resuscitation Research Laboratory at the University of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). UTMB provided animal experiment data and medical expertise support. Project results have been transferred to UTMB to benefit patient decision support and computerized drug delivery studies. Additionally, project results have been disseminated via multiple conference and journal publications and the PhD Theses of two graduate students.
